name: hafnium sponge production, from hafnium tetrachloride | hafnium sponge | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/26511/documentation

This dataset refers to the production of 1 kg of hafnium sponge from high-purity hafnium tetrachloride (HfCl4) (produced from the zirconium / hafnium separation process) by magnesium reduction and vaccum distillation (Kroll process - HfCl4 + 2Mg → Hf + 2MgCl2) in the US. The US is one of the major producers of hafnium sponge, representing 49.7% of the global production. ;The amounts of total magnesium input, hafnium tetrachloride input and total magnesium chloride produced as a byproduct are based on the abovementioned stoichiometric equation. Infrastructural input has been included for compliance with the Ecoinvent guidelines. Due to lack of data, the electricity consumption and inert waste during the hafnium sponge production process were approximated with the respective ones from the titanium sponge production dataset, since they are both produced via the Kroll process under similar conditions (consult dataset ''titanium sponge production, from titanium tetrachloride, GLO'' available in version 3.8 of the Ecoinvent database and the respective exchange comments in the present dataset). The amount of inert waste, taken from the aforementioned dataset, was adjusted based on the amount of magnesium chloride produced as byproduct.

The activity starts with the processing of high-purity hafnium tetrachloride (HfCl4).

The activity ends with the production of hafnium sponge. MgCl2 is produced as byproduct and is sent to an electrolysis process (modelled in a separate activity) in order to recover the magnesium and chlorine. The magnesium is refined and recycled back to the distillation and reduction process for producing hafnium sponge, while the chlorine is recycled back to the chlorination and extractive distillation process for the production of ZrCl4 and HfCl4.

No allocation is applied.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset valid for the entire corresponding region. The US is one of the major producers of hafnium sponge.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The HfCl4 is placed in a furnace at 850 °C and is subsequently reduced through the addition of magnesium. The stoichiometric equation is the following: HfCl4 + 2 Mg → Hf + 2 MgCl2. The produced hafnium sponge undergoes vacuum distillation, where the sponge is purified by removing the magnesium chloride, which is then separated via the electrolysis process, producing magnesium and chlorine (MgCl2 → Mg + Cl2). After refining, the magnesium is recycled and serves again as input to the reduction process, while chlorine (after it is filtrated and purified) is recycled and sent back to the chlorination process as an input.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Approximation of hafnium sponge production with the titanium sponge production, as they are both produced via the Kroll process under similar conditions. Uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
The amount of HfCl4, total magnesium (sum of recycled magnesium and non-recovered magnesium) and total magnesium chloride (without the minor loss - see below) were calculated based on the stoichiometric equation: HfCl4 + 2Mg → Hf + 2MgCl2. Infrastructure has been included for compliance with the Ecoinvent guidelines. An activity link has been set to the hafnium tetrachloride in order to ensure that hafnium tetrachloride is supplied from the producing activity of the same geography. An activity link has also been set to the magnesium chloride, to ensure that the magnesium chloride is sent to the electrolysis process in the same geography.

Furthermore, due to the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride (MgCl2 → Mg + Cl2), magnesium is produced as byproduct, which is recycled and fed back to the hafnium sponge production process (present dataset).

All other data (electricity consumption and inert waste) were taken as a proxy from the dataset ''titanium sponge production, from titanium tetrachloride, GLO'' as found in Ecoinvent version 3.8, which deals with the production of titanium sponge through the Kroll process (TiCl4+ 2Mg → Ti + 2MgCl2 - same process used for the production of hafnium sponge), which was based on the Gao et al. (2018) publication. The inert waste is assumed to be magnesium chloride that is lost thereby reducing the actual amount of produced magnesium chloride from 1.06685 kg to 1.0419 kg that is sent to electrolysis. The amount of inert waste taken from the aforementioned dataset was adjusted based on the amount of magnesium chloride produced as byproduct. The amount of recycled magnesium was based on the fact that the overall recovery rate of magnesium is 96%. These assumptions were taken from the abovementioned datasets. For more detailed information, the individual exchange comments have to be consulted.

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analy-sis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

flow.name: hafnium sponge
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of recycled magnesium that is required as input during the production of 1 kg of hafnium sponge. The recycled magnesium is obtained from the electrolysis of magnesium chloride. 

The amount of recycled magnesium is calculated by multiplying the amount of magnesium produced as byproduct during the electrolysis of 1 kg of magnesium chloride (roughly 0.25097 kg - consult exchange ''magnesium, for reuse in hafnium sponge production'' in the dataset ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'', available in version 3.8 of the Ecoinvent database), by the amount of magnesium chloride produced as byproduct during the production of 1 kg of hafnium sponge (1.0419 kg - consult exchange ''magnesium chloride, from hafnium sponge production'' in the present dataset).

[Note: The resulting overall recovery rate of magnesium is approximately 96%, which is expected considering that the dataset ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from hafnium sponge production'' was approximated with the dataset ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'', available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent database, In the latter dataset, it was calculated that the recovery rate of magnesium is 96% (for more information, consult the exchange comment ''magnesium, for reuse in titanium sponge production'' in that dataset).

flow.name: magnesium, for reuse in hafnium sponge production

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the inert waste produced as a byproduct during the production of 1 kg of hafnium sponge. It is assumed that this residue represents magnesium chloride that is lost in this step. 

Due to absence of data for the wastes during the production of hafnium sponge through the Kroll process, the amount of inert waste reported in the dataset ''titanium sponge production, from titanium tetrachloride'' available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent database was considered here (0.093 kg) and is assumed here as the best available approximation, since titanium sponge is also produced through the Kroll process. However, due to the structure of the dataset, the abovementioned value in that dataset is multiplied by a scaling factor, which is based on the magnesium chloride produced as a byproduct during the process. This scaling factor equals the ratio of magnesium chloride produced as a byproduct during the production of 1 kg of hafnium sponge (1.06685 kg) to the amount of magnesium chloride produced as a byproduct during the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (3.978 kg - consult the abovementioned dataset). Therefore, the scaling factor is approximately equal to 0.26819. 

[Note: The inert waste serves as a proxy for the output ''other residue'' that comes out of the process as a byproduct during the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge. The original value was taken from table 2, column ''reduction and distillation'' of the Gao et al. (2018) publication. 

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240).]

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of electricity required for the production of 1 kg of hafnium sponge. 

Due to absence of data, the amount of electricity consumption was taken as a proxy from the dataset ''titanium sponge production, from titanium tetrachloride, GLO'' as found in Ecoinvent version 3.8, which deals with the production of titanium sponge through the Kroll process (TiCl4+ 2Mg → Ti + 2MgCl2 - same process used for the production of hafnium sponge).

[Note: The aforementioned dataset was based on the Gao et al. (2018) publication. This publication reports an electricity consumption during the reduction and distillation process of 4.85E+03 kWh and represents the amount required for the production of 1 metric ton of titanium sponge (Table 2, column ''reduction and distillation''), which is assumed to be the same for the production of 1 metric ton of hafnium sponge. This value was scaled to represent the production of 1 kg of hafnium sponge.

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240).]

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of non-recovered magnesium that must be added separately in order to cover the stoichiometric amount that is required during the production of 1 kg of hafnium sponge.

The amount of non-recovered magnesium is calculated by subtracting the amount of recovered magnesium  from the amount of magnesium that is stoichiometrically required as input. The former amount (roughly 0.26149 kg) is represented by the exchange ''magnesium, for reuse in hafnium sponge production'' (consult the respective exchange comment) while the latter amount is based on the stoichiometric reaction HfCl4 + 2Mg → Hf + 2MgCl2, meaning that 0.27234 kg of magnesium is required as input per 1 kg of hafnium sponge.

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the magnesium chloride produced as a byproduct during the production of 1 kg of hafnium sponge. 

The amount of magnesium chloride produced as a byproduct is calculated by subtracting the assumed losses of magnesium chloride from the amount of magnesium chloride that is stoichiometrically produced. The former amount (roughly 0.02494 kg) is represented by the exchange ''inert waste'' (consult the respective exchange comment) while the latter amount (1.06685 kg) is based on the stoichiometric reaction HfCl4 + 2Mg → Hf + 2MgCl2, meaning that in the end 1.0419 kg of MgCl2 is produced as byproduct per 1 kg of hafnium sponge.
